NewsDetail.Title: Learning Model Reflection Series: Exercise Faith
NewsDetail.Abstract: We invite you to add your own thoughts and experiences by logging in below.
NewsDetail.Author: Brian Schmidt
NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
Principle One of the Learning Model states that “learners and teachers at BYU-Idaho exercise faith in the Lord Jesus Christ as a principle of action and power.”  Learning to act in accordance with one’s faith in Christ is fundamental to enjoying deep, life-changing learning.  Learners and teachers who center their faith in the Savior “look unto [Him] in every thought” such that they do not doubt their capacity to learn, nor fear their opportunities to teach (D&C 6:36).  The power we access by acting in faith that is focused on the Savior allows us to exceed our natural limits and learn beyond our natural capacities.


Several faculty members accepted an invitation to be interviewed on camera regarding their thoughts and experiences with the Learning Model.  This story features segments of these interviews and the exercise of faith in the classroom.  While not intended to cover the principle of “exercise faith in Jesus Christ” in a comprehensive fashion, these faculty insights might spark ideas and thoughts.  A brief quotation highlights each faculty member’s comments


 



Randall Kempton
Music Department

“When students and teachers are pushed to their edge—[When] they are pushed to the wall and cannot go any further with their light and they have to ask the Lord for help. He opens the doors in miraculous ways.”

David Ward
English Department

“One of the things that has been a very powerful influence in my life is to look to the Savior in my mind—and not just look to Him, but through Him to see my students.”

Stan Kivett
Religious Education Department

“...sometimes we underestimate the requirement of us… and how we need to yield, to submit, and pursue who He is and what He is—and in our in our own small ways try to become more like him...”

Steven Christenson
Biology Department

“What sets our apart . . .is that our very first principle says faith in Jesus Christ matters. . .. . As you live in accordance with the principles of the gospel of Jesus Christ, as you accept Him as your savior, there is a power that comes from that process.”
